metadata.title: Title: Intrinsic growth rules of patients infected, dead and cured with 2019 novel 1 coronavirus in mainland China 2

affiliation.laboratory: State Key Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience and Learning & IDG
Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Natural Disaster
State Key Laboratory of Earth Surface Processes and Resource Ecology

abstract.text: An outbreak of a novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2)-infected pneumonia was first occurred in Wuhan, China, in December 2019 and then spread rapidly to 35 other regions. It has been declared that at least one confirmed case infected by 36 SARS-CoV-2 was found in each province of China by late January 2020. 37

We collected the time series data of the cumulative number of confirmed infected, 39 dead, and cured cases from the health commissions in 31 provinces in mainland China. 40 A simple descriptive model in a logistic form was formulated to infer the intrinsic 41 epidemic rules of COVID-19. Furthermore, we compared the intrinsic epidemic rules 42 of COVID-19 in Hubei with that of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 43 Beijing, which was obtained from the Ministry of Public Health of China in 2003. 44

The feature of data of three population groups in all the provinces could be well 46 captured (R 2 >0.95) by the proposed descriptive model with slight variation among 47 (which was not peer-reviewed) The copyright holder for this preprint .

body_text.text: different provinces. By comparing fitted parameters, we found that the fitted curve of 48 infected case is the earliest to be saturated and has the lowest semi-saturation period 49 in both COVID-19 and SARS. While all three population groups of SARS is later to 50 saturate and has longer semi-saturation period than that of Conclusions 52

Our model is robust and stable to depict the intrinsic growth rule for the cumulative 53 number of confirmed infected, dead, and cured cases in 30 provinces, which could 54 depict the epidemic situation in mainland China very well. Despite the virus caused 55 SARS (SARS-CoV) and the virus caused COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) are homologous, 56 their epidemiologic characteristics are quite different. The duration of the outbreak 57 would be shorter for 59 . In December 2019, a novel coronavirus-infected pneumonia causing human infection 61 was first identified in Wuhan, a city of Hubei province located in central China with a 62 population of 11 million people (Zhu et al., 2020; Hui et al., 2020) . The coronavirus 63 was firstly named as 2019-nCoV on January 12, 2020 and may have a probable bat 64 origin (Zhou et al., 2020) . Human to human transmission through 2019-nCoV has 65 been confirmed among closed contacts since the middle of December 2019 (Wang et 66 al. 2020; Li et al., 2020) . As of February 12, 2020, infections of 2019-nCoV have been 67 identified in all Chinese provincial administrative regions and in dozens of countries 68 around the world (Munster et al., 2020; Holshue et al, 2020; Ki et al., 2020; 69 Shigemura et al., 2020; Nshiera et al., 2020) . So far, the coronavirus has been 70 renamed as COVID-19 on February 12, 2020 officially. Different from a previous 71 famous beta coronavirus in 2003, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 72 (SARS-CoV) (Ksiazek et al., 2003; Kuiken et al., 2003; Drosten et al., 2003) China. Furthermore, we compared these characteristics with SARS in 2003 using the 81 same model structure in order to validate this model and understand the differences 82 among these two diseases. 83 84 . (which was not peer-reviewed) The copyright holder for this preprint . https: //doi.org/10.1101 //doi.org/10. /2020
We obtained the time series data of 2019-nCoV cases from the National Health 87

Commission of China, and the provincial Health Commission of 31 provincial 88 administrative regions in Mainland China (January 20 to February 19, 2020). The data 89 used in this study include the number of confirmed 2019-nCoV cases, the cumulative 90 number of suspected, dead, and cured cases. All cases were laboratory confirmed 91 following the case definition by national health commission of China (from CCDC 92 website). The basic test procedure has been described in detail in previous work 93 (Huang et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020) . We only chose the cases that are tested positive 94 by real-time RT-PCR with specific primers and probes to SARS-CoV-2 both at the 95 corresponding provincial CDC and the National Institute for Viral Disease Control at 96 CCDC. We assumed that the population of each region was susceptible to COVID-19, the 105 number of susceptible people per unit time was proportional to the number of 106 uninfected persons, and isolation or closure of the city could affect the spread effect of 107 infected to susceptible people to a certain extent. Previous studies have showed that 108 daily cumulative number of patients could be explained by logistic function (Huang et 109 al., 2003; Wang et al., 2003) . Based on the above assumption and previous studies, we 110 modeled the epidemic information of virus as logistic form (Eq. (1)) 111 . with custom scripts. The nonlinear least square (NLS) algorithm was adopted for data 135 fitting and parameter estimation. We used the MATLAB function "nlinfit" to 136 . Eq. (8) was used in this work as the descriptive model to depict the intrinsic growth 138 rule for infected, dead and cured cases. 139 140 . The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.23.20024802 doi: medRxiv preprint In our model, k is an important parameter to depict the intrinsic growth rule of 158 cumulative number of infected patients (Eq. (8)). Based on our assumption, the 159 growth pattern was supposed to follow a sigmoid form, and the parameter k here 160 denotes how rapid the number of infected cases get to saturate. If k is large, the S form 161 of the curve would be sharp, and the curve will rise up very quickly to be saturated to 162 the maximum number. While if k is only slightly larger than 0, the curve would show 163 a slow and smooth increase from 0 to the maximum. 164

To further illustrate the spatial distribution of the infected cases' growth pattern, we 166 exerted further analyses of the fitted infected case curves of 30 provinces. We 167 excluded Tibet in this analysis because the number of confirmed infected case did not 168 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10. 1101 /2020 increase since Jan 29, 2020. And the only one confirmed case in Tibet has been cured 169 on Feb 12. The spatial distribution of parameter k is shown in Fig 2A, illustrating  170 provinces varied in the increase patterns of cumulative infected cases. Fitted curves of 171 provinces such as Jilin and Qinghai has larger value of k, which means that the 172 number of infections peaked earlier in these regions than in other provinces. By 173 contrast, provinces like Hainan, Hebei, Ningxia, has smaller value of k than other 174 provinces, suggesting the infections of these provinces would continue increasing 175 when infections of other provinces reach saturation (Fig 2B) . Fig 2C shows We found the k value of fitted curves of infected SARS cases in Beijing was 0.18, 193 which was much lower than that of Hubei province of COVID-19 (k = 0.25) (Fig 3  194 ABC). Furthermore, we found that all 30 provinces' k value were significantly larger 195 than 0.18 (Fig 3D) . We also noted the t 0 of fitted curves of infected SARS cases in 196 . Moreover, the increasing rate (k) was negatively 198 correlated (Pearson, r=-0.47, p=0.0072) to semi-saturation period (Fig 3F) . We 199 concluded that at the provincial level, the COVID-19 spread more quickly than the 200 SARS did. The infections of COVID-19 increased more rapid and would reach 201 saturation earlier than SARS according to our model. by two parameters, k and t 0 (Fig 4 DEIJ) . We found that k values of the three types 211 cases of SARS were lower than that of COVID-19 (Fig 4 DE) , and semi-saturation 212 period for them in SARS was higher than COVID-19's, which suggested the duration 213 of COVID-19 would be shorter than that of SARS. For both 214 their infected curves have the lowest semi-saturation period (Fig 4 EJ) , while cured 215 curves have the highest which is in keeping with the common sense that the cure is 216

Hubei, the k values of death case curves were lowest compared with curves of 218 infected cases and cured cases. For both SARS and COVID-19, the k value of infected 219 case curve was larger than that of cured curve. body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint . https: //doi.org/10.1101 //doi.org/10. /2020
We modeled the epidemiologic characteristics of 2019-nCoV for 31 provinces in 225 mainland China based on the data from Jan 20 to Feb 19 during the outbreak. 226
Furthermore, we compared these characteristics with SARS in 2003 using the same 227 model framework. 228
Compared with dynamical models such as SIR (Susceptible -Infectious -Recovered) 230

or SEIR (Susceptible -Exposed -Infectious -Recovered), our model is relatively 231 simple but robust. We used a differential equation in logistic form to describe the 232 dynamics of the infected, dead and healed cases caused by COVID-19 respectively 233 (See Methods). The increasing of the population no matter in which type of case 234 (infection, death or recovery) has multiple reasons. When the outbreak of COVID-19 235 originated in Wuhan, it did not cause too much concern at the beginning so that it 236 leads to many infections and starts to export potential exposed cases to other 237 provinces. But as the successive closure of the cities in Hubei province, and isolation 238 of the community in all the provinces in mainland China, the virus spread tendency 239 was weakened. In our model, we also considered these measures taken by the 240 government. We rewrote Eq. (1) to Eq. (9). CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.23.20024802 doi: medRxiv preprint cured cases will rise up quickly. The growth of cured cases would again be slow since 252 the number of patients is limited. All these facts were considered in our highly 253 summarized model (Eq. (8) ) in a macroscopic scale. All data sets have a R-square 254 greater than 0.95 when fitted by our framework, so that we could further discuss some will be quicker to pass away than SARS. For both SARS and COVID-19, fitted 279 . The copyright holder for this preprint . https: //doi.org/10.1101 //doi.org/10. /2020 curves of infections have lowest semi-saturation period (Fig 4 EK) , while fitted 280 curves of cured cases have the highest semi-saturation period, which follows the 281 common sense that the cure was always later than infection and death since it costs 282 time to get on the research of effect plans to cure the patients. For both SARS and 283 COVID-19, the k value of infected case curve was larger than that of cured curve, 284

while that of death case is the lowest. 285 286 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

FIGREF2.text: of the 31 Chinese provincial administrative region. So far, there have been a 143 total of 75002 confirmed cases of 2019-nCoV infections in mainland China, including 144 2118 deaths and 16157 cases cured (From CCDC). Hubei province contributed a 145 majority of cases to this statistical numbers (Fig 1A). Based on the limited infected 146 case data in the early and middle phase of this new coronavirus outbreak, we firstly 147 established a descriptive model with three parameters for each of the 31 provinces in 148 mainland China by (Fig 1B & Fig 2B, See Methods). Fitting goodness of models was 149 expressed by the R-square, which ranged from 0.95 to 0.999, indicating that the 150 models we established fitted the data well. The panel B of Figure 1 illustrates 151 examples of time series data of infected cases and corresponding fitting curves in four 152 provinces (provinces of Xinjiang, Beijing, Guangdong, Zhejiang and Heilongjiang). It 153 is clear that different province varied in patterns of increase of infected cases. 154 155 ------------------------------Insert Figure 1 near here ---------------------------------------156 157

Since the time series data of SARS was full phase 191 of the outbreak, the parameters estimated by our model was solid (R-square>0.95).

FIGREF5.text: -----------------------------Insert Figure 3 near here ---------------------------------------204 205 The outbreak of SARS in Beijing was the most serious among all the provincial 206 administrative regions, and the outbreak of COVID-19 was most serious in Hubei 207 province. Here we used our descriptive model to fit the dead and cured cases' curves 208 for SARS in Beijing and COVID-19 in Hubei province (Fig 4 A-C, F-H, R-square≥ 209 0.95), and compared the growth features of three types cases of SARS and COVID-19 210

FIGREF7.text: growth rate of the number of infections; I(t) is cumulative number of 243 infections at time t; could be understood as a parameter to reflect the effect of 244 measures aiming at controlling the virus spread. Here we have decomposed into 245 two parts. The first part could represent the rapid infections growth in the early 246 phase of the outbreak without any measures for epidemic control. The second part 247 ! illustrates the slower infections growth after taking effective isolation 248 measures for epidemic control. For death cases, this idea still holds. But things are 249 different for cured case. In contrast, at the early phase of the outbreak, the number of 250 cured cases increase slowly. But once there are effective treatments, the number of 251 .

FIGREF8.text: 255 intrinsic mechanisms for the growth rules of infection, death and recovery through the 256 parameters estimated from the model (See Methods). 257 258 The value of k from Eq. (8) is a critical parameter. k represents how rapid the number 259 of infected cases get to the saturation. We found the variability of k values among 260 fitted curves of infected COVID-19 cases in 30 provinces (Fig 2 AB) is large 261 (Ranging from 0.19 to 0.38). It is clear to show the real situation in each province and 262 this guides us to be more careful against the epidemic. Further we compared this 263 characteristics between COVID-19 and SARS in 2003 in typical provinces (Fig 3 AB). 264 We noted that k values of fitted COVID-19 infection curves in 30 provinces of 265 mainland China (exclude Tibet) are larger than that of SARS in Beijing 2003 (Fig 3 266 C), which suggests the time cost of this epidemic will be shorter compared with 267 SARS in 2003. This result may related to several aspects. Firstly, it may due to the 268 basic spread property of the virus. Besides, the isolation policy of all the provinces in 269 mainland China was more strictly enforced than it was in 2003. Moreover, the 270 improved clinical skills today may also helpful for shortening the duration of 271 epidemic. 272 273 Furthermore, we analyzed semi-saturation period (Fig 4 EK) (t 0 in Eq. (8)) and make 274 comparison in three types of cases (infection, death and recovery) (Fig 4 A-C G-I). 275 Our model could fit them very well (R-square ≥ ( − ). k values for the fitted 276 curves of the three types of cases caused by COVID-19 were larger than that of SARS, 277 while t 0 values were the opposite. This again suggests that the epidemic of COVID-19 278

TABREF1.text: the spatial 176 distribution of predicted maximum number of infected cases (parameter A) in each 177 province of mainland China. Our model shows that the maximum number of infected 178 COVID-19 cases in mainland China would be 81498 (95% confidence interval: 179 [79099, 83896]). Among all the provinces in mainland China, the Hubei province is 180 predicted to have largest number of infected COVID-19 cases, which would be 68056 181 (95% confidence interval: [65679,70432]). Despite Tibet is predicted to have only one 182 infected case, the model predicted Qinghai province would have 19 cases (95% 183 confidence interval: [18, 19]), which is the fewest compared with other provinces in 184
